title: 109_hr377
content: The Act may be cited as the "Honoring Every Requirement of Exemplary Service Act of 2005" or the "HEROES Act of 2005". Death gratuity enhancements are included in the Act. The "HEROES Act of 2005" includes death gratuity enhancements, increasing the death gratuity to $100,000 for deaths resulting from combat-related causes or causes incurred in designated operations or areas. The "HEROES Act of 2005" increases death gratuity to $100,000 for combat-related deaths or deaths in designated operations or areas. This includes adjustments to the death gratuity amounts and a requirement to pay additional gratuity for deaths before the effective date. The "HEROES Act of 2005" mandates an additional death gratuity for members of the Armed Forces who died before the enactment date due to wounds, injuries, or illnesses. The "HEROES Act of 2005" mandates an additional death gratuity of $238,000 for beneficiaries of Armed Forces members who died before the enactment date due to specific conditions related to military service. The "HEROES Act of 2005" provides an additional death gratuity to beneficiaries of Armed Forces members who died before the enactment date. If there are multiple beneficiaries, the amount each receives is based on the ratio of their regular military death gratuity share to the total amount payable. The "HEROES Act of 2005" provides an additional death gratuity to beneficiaries of Armed Forces members who died before the enactment date. The term "regular military death gratuity" refers to a death gratuity payable under specific sections of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 3. SERVICEMEMBERS' GROUP LIFE INSURANCE ENHANCEMENTS. Increased Maximum Amount Under Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance to $400,000 or lesser amount chosen by member, with additional coverage for certain members. The amount of insurance provided for members under subsection (e) is increased from $250,000 to $400,000. Additionally, members serving in specific areas or operations designated by the Secretary are eligible for further coverage. The insurance coverage for members is increased to $400,000 under subsection (e). Members serving in designated combat operations or zones are eligible for an additional $150,000 in insurance, which may be reduced if the member already has coverage exceeding $250,000. The insurance coverage for members is capped at $400,000 under this subchapter, with an additional $150,000 available for those serving in designated operations. Any excess coverage above $250,000 will be reduced to comply with the limit. For designated operations, an additional $150,000 in insurance coverage is provided for members under this subchapter. Coordination with VGLI is also amended in accordance with these changes. In coordination with VGLI, insurance coverage for members is increased to $400,000, excluding insurance provided under specific circumstances. Additionally, regulations regarding member elections to decline insurance are amended. Regulations require notice to be given to a member's spouse if the member elects not to be insured or chooses a lower coverage amount. Additionally, a member with a spouse cannot decline insurance without the spouse's written consent. Members with spouses must obtain written consent from their spouse before modifying beneficiaries designated under subsection (a). This requirement will take effect more than 90 days after the enactment of the Act.
